articles.headline: Trump and Kim Jong-un to Hold Second Summit Meeting Next Month
articles.snippet: Negotiations over eliminating North Korea’s nuclear arsenal have made little progress since the two leaders’ June meeting in Singapore.
articles.abstract: Negotiations over eliminating North Korea’s nuclear arsenal have made little progress since the two leaders’ June meeting in Singapore.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump will meet with North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, in late February, the White House announced on Friday, renewing a high-level diplomatic dialogue that has eased tensions with a rogue nuclear state but has shown no progress in eliminating its nuclear arsenal.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: 4,141 Latvians Were Just Outed as K.G.B. Informants
articles.snippet: Is the newly released Soviet-era archive a real record of collaboration or a time bomb planted by agents as the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991?
articles.abstract: Is the newly released Soviet-era archive a real record of collaboration or a time bomb planted by agents as the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991?
articles.lead_paragraph: KUKAS, Latvia — Back in Soviet times, Yuris Taskovs snitched to the K.G.B. about a neighbor watching German pornography and betrayed hundreds of anti-Kremlin activists. So he and others like him knew that if the secret police files from Latvia were ever made public, which they finally were last month, their nefarious activities would be revealed.

articles.headline: Jason Van Dyke Sentenced to Nearly 7 Years for Murdering Laquan McDonald
articles.snippet: Mr. Van Dyke was the first Chicago police officer in decades convicted of murder for an on-duty shooting. He shot Laquan 16 times in 2014.
articles.abstract: Mr. Van Dyke was the first Chicago police officer in decades convicted of murder for an on-duty shooting. He shot Laquan 16 times in 2014.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — On a bleak stretch of road outside a Burger King four years ago, a white police officer opened fire on a black teenage boy. Captured on a dashboard camera, the killing reshaped Chicago.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: F.T.C. Is Said to Be Considering Large Facebook Fines
articles.snippet: The agency’s investigation, which began in late March, is continuing, and the commissioners and staff have not reached a final conclusion.
articles.abstract: The agency’s investigation, which began in late March, is continuing, and the commissioners and staff have not reached a final conclusion.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission is in the advanced stages of its investigation into whether Facebook violated privacy rules and is expected to seek large fines from the company, according to two people familiar with the inquiry.

articles.headline: As Beto O’Rourke Weighs 2020 Run, Democrats Chafe at His Go-It-Alone Style
articles.snippet: Some Democrats still blame Mr. O’Rourke for his embrace of a Texas Republican, Will Hurd, and wonder whether he can be counted on as a liberal ally.
articles.abstract: Some Democrats still blame Mr. O’Rourke for his embrace of a Texas Republican, Will Hurd, and wonder whether he can be counted on as a liberal ally.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a moment in August, an event hall in Texas teemed with hope, taquitos and unity.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: John Bercow, Shouting for ‘Order’ Amid Chaos, Is Brexit’s Surprise Star and Villain
articles.snippet: Speaker John Bercow has overturned precedent to give the British Parliament a bigger role in Brexit.
articles.abstract: Speaker John Bercow has overturned precedent to give the British Parliament a bigger role in Brexit.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the wretched purgatory that was Westminster last week, there was precisely one person who seemed to be having fun.

articles.headline: Shutdown Prompts Centrist Freshman Democrats to Flex Their Muscles
articles.snippet: While flashy liberal freshmen soak up the attention, more moderate Democrats who won G.O.P. districts in November are searching for compromise to end the shutdown.
articles.abstract: While flashy liberal freshmen soak up the attention, more moderate Democrats who won G.O.P. districts in November are searching for compromise to end the shutdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the most diverse freshman class in history settles into the House of Representatives, newcomers like Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York and Rashida Tlaib of Michigan have been racking up social media followers and soaking up the spotlight, liberal firebrands largely elected to safe Democratic seats.

articles.headline: Trump Offers Temporary Protections for ‘Dreamers’ in Exchange for Wall Funding
articles.snippet: President Trump cast the proposal, which included $5.7 billion for a border barrier, as a compromise as he sought to shift pressure to Democrats to end the government shutdown.
articles.abstract: President Trump cast the proposal, which included $5.7 billion for a border barrier, as a compromise as he sought to shift pressure to Democrats to end the government shutdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, facing a growing public backlash over the partial government shutdown, shifted course on Saturday and offered Democrats a deal: temporary protections for roughly 700,000 young undocumented immigrants in exchange for $5.7 billion in funding for a wall along the southern border.
articles.byline: By Annie Karni and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: In Trump’s Immigration Announcement, a Compromise Snubbed All Around
articles.snippet: Seeking to appeal to a broader swath of the public and end the government shutdown, President Trump alienated portions of his hard-right base and made no headway with Democratic congressional leaders.
articles.abstract: Seeking to appeal to a broader swath of the public and end the government shutdown, President Trump alienated portions of his hard-right base and made no headway with Democratic congressional leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Immigrant advocates denounced it as cruel. The conservative right howled that it was amnesty.

articles.headline: The Stock Market Is Making a Comeback. Was It Something the Fed Said?
articles.snippet: The year began with repeated public assurances from Fed officials that they would remain sensitive to changes in the economy. And the markets’ anxiety has eased.
articles.abstract: The year began with repeated public assurances from Fed officials that they would remain sensitive to changes in the economy. And the markets’ anxiety has eased.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks have staged a remarkable turnaround in the early days of 2019, rebounding after an end-of-the-year tailspin that was fomented by fears of recession in the United States.

articles.headline: Amazon Knows What You Buy. And It’s Building a Big Ad Business From It.
articles.snippet: The online retail giant is taking advantage of what it knows better than anyone: consumers’ online shopping habits.
articles.abstract: The online retail giant is taking advantage of what it knows better than anyone: consumers’ online shopping habits.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — When a chain of physical therapy centers wanted new patients, it aimed online ads at people near its offices who had bought knee braces recently on Amazon.

articles.headline: How Do You Govern Machines That Can Learn? Policymakers Are Trying to Figure That Out
articles.snippet: Dozens of senior policymakers who are trying to agree on rules for artificial intelligence gathered at M.I.T. There was even some consensus.
articles.abstract: Dozens of senior policymakers who are trying to agree on rules for artificial intelligence gathered at M.I.T. There was even some consensus.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Hal Abelson, a renowned computer scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was working the classroom, coffee cup in hand, pacing back and forth. The subject was artificial intelligence, and his students last week were mainly senior policymakers from countries in the 36-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

articles.headline: China’s Slowdown Looms Just as the World Looks for Growth
articles.snippet: In the past, China has helped to pull the global economy out of weak spots. This time, it might not come through.
articles.abstract: In the past, China has helped to pull the global economy out of weak spots. This time, it might not come through.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In the vast metropolis of Chongqing in western China, three huge Ford Motor assembly plants have slowed to a fraction of their earlier pace.

articles.headline: Republicans Push Trump Immigration Plan, Seeking to Corner Democrats on Shutdown
articles.snippet: Republican leaders hope to pressure Democrats — who insist they won’t negotiate with President Trump on border security until the shutdown ends — not to block Mr. Trump’s proposal.
articles.abstract: Republican leaders hope to pressure Democrats — who insist they won’t negotiate with President Trump on border security until the shutdown ends — not to block Mr. Trump’s proposal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump attacked Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Sunday for rejecting his proposal to end the partial government shutdown, as he and Republican leaders in Congress sought to put Democrats on defense, a place they have rarely been during the shutdown stalemate.

articles.headline: Moscow Skyscraper Talks Continued Through ‘the Day I Won,’ Trump Is Said to Acknowledge
articles.snippet: The Trump Tower Moscow talks went on for months longer than the president has previously acknowledged, his lawyer said.
articles.abstract: The Trump Tower Moscow talks went on for months longer than the president has previously acknowledged, his lawyer said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump was involved in discussions to build a skyscraper in Moscow throughout the entire 2016 presidential campaign, his personal lawyer said on Sunday, a longer and more significant role for Mr. Trump than he had previously acknowledged.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Rebuilding a Puerto Rico Barrio: ‘Dead Is the Only Way They’ll Ever Get Me to Leave’
articles.snippet: Hurricane Maria led to a host of new plans to fix island barrios plagued by chronic flooding. A look at the Vietnam neighborhood shows why they may never be achieved.
articles.abstract: Hurricane Maria led to a host of new plans to fix island barrios plagued by chronic flooding. A look at the Vietnam neighborhood shows why they may never be achieved.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUAYNABO, P.R. — Victor Manuel Torres raised one hand, about waist level, indicating how high the sea rose in his house during Hurricane Maria last year.
articles.byline: By Michael Kimmelman and Christopher Gregory

articles.headline: BuzzFeed News in Limbo Land
articles.snippet: From the posting of the dossier to the publication of a story now in dispute, BuzzFeed News is learning about the perils of the chase.
articles.abstract: From the posting of the dossier to the publication of a story now in dispute, BuzzFeed News is learning about the perils of the chase.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is, in many respects, a golden age for journalism.

articles.headline: In Business and Governing, Trump Seeks Victory in Chaos
articles.snippet: For people who have done business with the president, the protracted fight over the government shutdown reflects a time-tested playbook.
articles.abstract: For people who have done business with the president, the protracted fight over the government shutdown reflects a time-tested playbook.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three decades ago, Donald J. Trump waged a public battle with the talk show host Merv Griffin to take control of what would become Mr. Trump’s third Atlantic City casino. Executives at Mr. Trump’s company warned that the casino would siphon revenue from the others. Analysts predicted the associated debt would crush him.
articles.byline: By Russ Buettner and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: U.S. Policy on Russia? Trump and His Team Might Give Different Answers
articles.snippet: President Trump says that he has done more to counter Russian aggression than other recent presidents. But, officials say, Mr. Trump has gone along with such actions reluctantly or under pressure.
articles.abstract: President Trump says that he has done more to counter Russian aggression than other recent presidents. But, officials say, Mr. Trump has gone along with such actions reluctantly or under pressure.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After Russian forces seized three Ukrainian ships in November and threatened to turn the Sea of Azov into a Russian lake, Trump administration officials outlined possible responses like imposing additional sanctions, sending ships to make port calls or deploying monitors.

articles.headline: Kamala Harris Declares Candidacy, Evoking King and Joining Diverse Field
articles.snippet: The senator from California, a former prosecutor and one of the most prominent black women in politics, is the fourth woman to announce she is running in 2020.
articles.abstract: The senator from California, a former prosecutor and one of the most prominent black women in politics, is the fourth woman to announce she is running in 2020.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Kamala Harris, the California Democrat and barrier-breaking prosecutor who became the second black woman to serve in the United States Senate, declared her candidacy for president on Monday, joining an increasingly crowded and diverse field in what promises to be a wide-open nomination process.

articles.headline: After Deadly Assault on Afghan Base, Taliban Sit for Talks With U.S. Diplomats
articles.snippet: At least 40 Afghans working for the country’s intelligence agency were killed in a militant assault on their base in Wardak Province, one of the single deadliest such attacks in 17 years of war.
articles.abstract: At least 40 Afghans working for the country’s intelligence agency were killed in a militant assault on their base in Wardak Province, one of the single deadliest such attacks in 17 years of war.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban infiltrated an Afghan intelligence base on Monday, killing dozens of people in what Afghan officials said was one of the deadliest attacks against the intelligence service in the 17-year war with the Taliban.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal, Fahim Abed and Fatima Faizi
